MESH+ Module

Detailed Description

An abstract layer for the Meshes:.

  • IMesh objects are used to create 3D animated meshes, constructed of a number of vertices and faces.
  • The IMeshBuffer and its derivatives, IMeshVertexBuffer and IMeshFaceBuffer, provide underlying hardware buffers.
  • IMeshDictionary object used for mapping bone names to indices

Remarks:
The most common situation is when you load a Scene or a Scene Meshed Object from a file (see IFileLoader::LoadScene, IFileLoader::LoadObject). All the needed meshes will be then created and initialised automatically.

Buffer Creation and Usage

Buffers (IMeshVertexBuffer and IMeshFaceBuffer specialised interfaces) provide indispensable link for the Meshes to the underlying low-level systems (eg. DirectX, OGL). They are highly platform-dependent components and therefore are implemented in RENDER+ module (see FWRender::MeshDX9VertexBuffer and FWRender::MeshDX9FaceBuffer). They should never be created directly. Instead, use IRndrGeneric::GetVertexBuffer and IRndrGeneric::GetFaceBuffer functions that create them. The creation process is two-stage, and must involve further call to IMeshVertexBuffer::Create and IMeshFaceBuffer::Create, respectively.
Remarks:
The actual data format of the created buffers may differ from what was requested, depending on the local system capabilities. Call IMeshVertexBuffer::GetFormat or IMeshFaceBuffer::GetFormat to verify the actual format.
Once the buffer is created, any low-level operations should be preceded with a call to IMeshBuffer::Open and terminated with a call to IMeshBuffer::Close. Putting or modifying the buffer raw data is generally the user's responsibility and should be done using the pointer got during opening, however in the IMesh interface one can find a bundle of usefull facility functions.
Remarks:
When acting with the beuufer data directly, use IMeshVertexBuffer::GetFormat, IMeshVertexBuffer::GetCaps and IMeshFaceBuffer::GetFormat to determine the data layout.

The Mesh Object (IMesh)

The IMesh objects together with a kinematical skeleton (KinePlus::KineBone) are put together into a ISceneObject object to form a fully functional object ready for rendering. Most often you will create IMesh objects with a ISceneObject::NewMesh facility function. In case you create mesh on your own call ISceneObject::AddMesh to include the mesh into the Scene Meshed Object and to initialise it accordingly.

The IMesh object needs to be initialised with IMeshVertexBuffer and IMeshFaceBuffer buffers as well as IMeshDictionary, however both ISceneObject::NewMesh and ISceneObject::AddMesh functions will do this initialisation for you.

The IMesh usage involves opening the raw data with IMesh::Open, filling the data and closing the buffers with IMesh::Close. For filling the data, a broad range of format-independent easy-to-use functions is provided. Alternatively (faster!) you can set data directly in the buffer bytes (see Buffer Creation and Usage).

General Data Support

General Data Support (GDS) is a set of functions that allow quick and easy setting the xyz, colouring, point size and texture attributes for vertices as well as index triples for faces without bothering with the actual buffer format. Call IMesh::Open before use.
See also:
IMesh::SetVertexXYZ and following functions.

Normal Vector Support

Normal Vector Support (NVS) allows setting the normal vectors for vertices; an important facility is that two or more normals per vector are allowed. This usually happens when a vertex is shared by two or more neighbouring smoothing areas, and forms a part of a 3d edge. It is essential to notice that a completely separate copy of a vertex (a clone) is created in the vertex buffer for each separate value of the normal vector. Therefore the vertex index may be changed during the IMesh::AddNormal call, and consequently it has been defined as an [in, out] param. When storing vertex indices as triangle definitions in the face buffer it is critical to call AddNormal first so that to use the appropriate clone, i.e. with the normal value used in the given face and the smoothing area. Notice, that several calls for the same vertex/normal pair will not lead to any redundant data.
Remarks:
  • To start using the NVS functionality, first call IMesh::SupportNormal
  • Then use IMesh::AddNormal to store normals.
  • NVS may allocate large temporary data structures (created by SupportBlendWeight, released by Close)
  • As use of NVS clones some vertices, it will lead to increasing the length of the used vertex buffer (IMesh::GetVertexNum), and occasionally may cause the FW_E_MEMOVERRUN error.

Vertex Blending Support

Vertex Blending Support (VBS) enables use of a single mesh spread on a number of bones. Vertices of such mesh may be controlled by two or more bones (blended control), with a weight assigned to each bone. You simply pass a set of bone weight/bone name pairs for each vertex, and VBS will translate the bone names to unique indices/ids using an IMeshDictionary object provided. Use the same dictionary instance for several meshes to keep consistency in bone ids.
Remarks:
  • To start using the VBS functionality, first call IMesh::SupportBlendWeight
  • Then use IMesh::AddBlendWeight.
  • VBS may allocate large temporary data structures (created by SupportBlendWeight, released by Close)
  • As use of VBS occasionally causes new vertices to be created, it may lead to the FW_E_MEMOVERRUN error.
  • see also the Submeshes section below.

Submeshes

Some hardware platforms do not support bone indices; similar situation occurs when MESH_VERTEX_BONEWEIGHT but not MESH_VERTEX_BONEINDEX buffer creation flags are applied. Subsequently only a limited set of globally defined bones may be used per mesh. If necessary, the VBS engine (see the Vertex Blending Support above) will divide and sort vertices into several submeshes, so that not to exceed the allowed number of bones in each submesh. This facility is implemented in IMesh::Close and may significantly increase the execution time of this function. Creation of submeshes significantly affects the way in which the mesh should be rendered (see below).

Remarks on Mesh Rendering

The Vertex and Face Buffer, initialised with data and finalised with IMesh::Close call are the general basis for rendering. However the use of Vertex Blending Support with Submeshes (see IMesh::MeshSub) may cause that multiple, relatively small submeshes shuld be rendered rather than the whole mesh. All the submeshes share the same Vertex/Face Buffers. First call IMesh::SupportsSubmeshedVertexBlending to check if this is the case; if positive, call IMesh::GetSubmeshInfo to collect details on submesh division.

Implementation Remarks

Vertex and Face Buffers are highly platform-dependent objects and are not implemented in the FreeWill+ module. See the external implementation classes FWRender::MeshDX9VertexBuffer and FWRender::MeshDX9FaceBuffer.

The Mesh implementation is platform-independent and unlikely to be replaced in the future extensions, see FreeWillPlus::Mesh, so is the auxiliary class FreeWillPlus::MeshDictionary.

Buffer Open Modes.

Identifies various modes in which a buffer can be open.

See IMeshBuffer::Open.

enum  MESH_OPENMODES { MESH_OPEN_READ = 0, MESH_OPEN_APPEND = 1, MESH_OPEN_MODIFY = 2, MESH_OPEN_UNUSED = 0x7fffffff }

Vertex Format Tags

Identifies various items of the vertex structure.

See IMeshVertexBuffer::GetCaps.

Remarks:
Values of this enumeration correspond to MESH_VERTEX calues as indices to mask flags.


enum  MESH_VERTEXID {
  MESH_VERTEXID_XYZ = 0, MESH_VERTEXID_NORMAL = 1, MESH_VERTEXID_POINTSIZE = 2, MESH_VERTEXID_DIFFUSE = 3,
  MESH_VERTEXID_SPECULAR = 4, MESH_VERTEXID_BONEWEIGHT = 5, MESH_VERTEXID_BONEINDEX = 6, MESH_VERTEXID_TEXTURE = 7,
  MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED1 = 8, MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED2 = 9, MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED3 = 10, MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED4 = 11,
  MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED5 = 12, MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED6 = 13, MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED7 = 14, MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED8 = 15,
  MESH_VERTEXID_UNUSED = 0x7fffffff
}

Vertex Format Requirement flags

Defines required items of the vertex format.

See IMeshVertexBuffer::Create. The actual format of the created buffer may be slightly different:

  • implementation may ignore some flags; check Format attr to check which specifiers have been applied
  • implementation may decrease nBones/nTextures values if technical restrictions apply
  • implementation may use own extended flags not listed below (first 16 bits are reserved)

Remarks:
Values of this enumeration correspond to MESH_VERTEXID calues mask flags to their indices


enum  MESH_VERTEX {
  MESH_VERTEX_XYZ = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_XYZ, MESH_VERTEX_NORMAL = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_NORMAL, MESH_VERTEX_POINTSIZE = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_POINTSIZE, MESH_VERTEX_DIFFUSE = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_DIFFUSE,
  MESH_VERTEX_SPECULAR = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_SPECULAR, MESH_VERTEX_BONEWEIGHT = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_BONEWEIGHT, MESH_VERTEX_BONEINDEX = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_BONEINDEX, MESH_VERTEX_TEXTURE = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_TEXTURE,
  MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED1 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED1, MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED2 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED2, MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED3 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED3, MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED4 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED4,
  MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED5 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED5, MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED6 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED6, MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED7 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED7, MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED8 = 1 << MESH_VERTEXID_RESERVED8,
  MESH_VERTEX_UNUSED = 0x7fffffff
}

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum MESH_OPENMODES
 

Enumeration values:
MESH_OPEN_READ  buffer open to read only; see IMeshBuffer::Open
MESH_OPEN_APPEND  buffer open to append (write) new bytes beyond the end of data; see IMeshBuffer::Open
MESH_OPEN_MODIFY  buffer open to read and write; see IMeshBuffer::Open

Definition at line 176 of file meshplus.idl.

enum MESH_VERTEX
 

Enumeration values:
MESH_VERTEX_XYZ  vertex (x, y, z) position
MESH_VERTEX_NORMAL  vertex normal
MESH_VERTEX_POINTSIZE  point size
MESH_VERTEX_DIFFUSE  vertex diffuse colour
MESH_VERTEX_SPECULAR  vertex specular colour
MESH_VERTEX_BONEWEIGHT  bone wieghts (total number of bones passed in nBones; nBones >= 2 - see IMeshVertexBuffer::Create)
MESH_VERTEX_BONEINDEX  bone indices; number of indices will be equal to total number of bones nBones
MESH_VERTEX_TEXTURE  texture co-ordinates; total number of coordinates should be passed in nTextures
MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED1  reserved for future extensions
MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED2  reserved for future extensions
MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED3  reserved for future extensions
MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED4  reserved for future extensions
MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED5  reserved for future extensions
MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED6  reserved for future extensions
MESH_VERTEX_RESERVED7  reserved for future extensions
